repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
I was confused by what some `nvim_set_current_*` functions did and updated the docs to match their behaviour. It also wasn't clear what they returned, but it turns out to be winid so I updated the docs to say that instead of "window handle" (which seems to be the C name for it).

Also added a help section for the tab equivalent of winid. Seems like only neovim exposes this value. I named it tab ID to match window ID.

~I'm not setup to generate vim help docs or compile neovim, so I haven't tested these changes.~

----

* Clarify behaviour of nvim_set_current_*

Fix generic descriptions that don't specify that nvim_set_current_line
modifies contents but nvim_set_current_buf does not, etc.

* Use window-ID for return types

Make it clear that these functions accept or return a winid by linking
to that concept in help.

Only these few files use the term "window handles", so replace them with
vim terminology for clarity.

* Add tab-ID to document tabpage return type

Add a new help section for tab-ID. This concept is unique to neovim
because vim exposes tabnr, but not tab handles. This section is modelled
after `:h winid`.

Only api.txt uses the term "tabpage handle", so replace with something
clearly defined and symmetrical to win-ID.

Make it clear that tabpage functions accept or return tab ID by linking
to that concept in help.

comment_data.body: This isn't true if the buffer is already loaded. "Set" is probably the right word here.
Moving the cursor is just a consequence of setting the current window. Again I think the old text is more accurate. Can still include that it changes the tab page.
Yeah this shouldn't be changed. The old wording was exactly correct.

This is a useful change. The "handle" jargon isn't used much, and was mostly introduced because of our use of msgpack "extension types", which tried to give a clever object-oriented interface to buffers/windows/tabs.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -810,13 +810,13 @@ nvim_get_current_tabpage()                        *nvim_get_current_tabpage()*
     Gets the current tabpage.
 
     Return: ~
-        Tabpage handle
+        |tab-ID|
 
 nvim_get_current_win()                                *nvim_get_current_win()*
     Gets the current window.
 
     Return: ~
-        Window handle
+        |window-ID|

@@ -1269,7 +1269,7 @@ nvim_set_client_info({name}, {version}, {type}, {methods}, {attributes})
                         icon. .png or .svg format is preferred.
 
 nvim_set_current_buf({buffer})                        *nvim_set_current_buf()*
-    Sets the current buffer.
+    Loads `buffer` in the current window.

@@ -1284,7 +1284,7 @@ nvim_set_current_dir({dir})                           *nvim_set_current_dir()*
       • {dir}  Directory path
 
 nvim_set_current_line({line})                        *nvim_set_current_line()*
-    Sets the current line.
+    Changes the text on the current line.

@@ -1293,22 +1293,22 @@ nvim_set_current_line({line})                        *nvim_set_current_line()*
       • {line}  Line contents
 
 nvim_set_current_tabpage({tabpage})               *nvim_set_current_tabpage()*
-    Sets the current tabpage.
+    Switches to view `tabpage`.

@@ -1293,22 +1293,22 @@ nvim_set_current_line({line})                        *nvim_set_current_line()*
       • {line}  Line contents
 
 nvim_set_current_tabpage({tabpage})               *nvim_set_current_tabpage()*
-    Sets the current tabpage.
+    Switches to view `tabpage`.
 
     Attributes: ~
         not allowed when |textlock| is active or in the |cmdwin|
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {tabpage}  Tabpage handle
+      • {tabpage}  |tab-ID| to focus
 
 nvim_set_current_win({window})                        *nvim_set_current_win()*
-    Sets the current window.
+    Move cursor to `window`. Also changes tabpage, if necessary.

@@ -32,6 +32,17 @@ Tabs are also a nice way to edit a buffer temporarily without changing the
 current window layout.  Open a new tab page, do whatever you want to do and
 close the tab page.
 
+							*tab-ID* *tabid* *tabpageid*

comment_data.body: FYI: `#` also should work, if tooling is getting confused. I didn't know that `:` could be used like this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -306,7 +306,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns a list of highlight capture names under the cursor
 ---
----@param winnr (integer|nil) Window handle or 0 for current window (default)
+---@param winnr (integer|nil): |window-ID| or 0 for current window (default)

@@ -306,7 +306,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns a list of highlight capture names under the cursor
 ---
----@param winnr (integer|nil) Window handle or 0 for current window (default)
+---@param winnr (integer|nil): |window-ID| or 0 for current window (default)

comment_regular_data.body: Please do not use the word "input".
@justinmk Do you think that we should document the preferred terminology of some of these concepts in our maintenance docs?

repo.description: PR fork of a Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: doc: Clarify window-id and tab-id return values; clarify nvim_set_current_*
